I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During Asian Development Bank (ADB) operational missions in 2005, the Government of 
the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  requested  assistance  for  preparing  the 
Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Northern Power Transmission Project. The project aims to 
support  GMS  members’  strategies  for  promoting  regional  power  exchange  and to  electrify 
northern rural Lao PDR. The project will develop and strengthen power interconnections with 
Thailand and extend the existing transmission lines and distribution facilities in northern Lao 
PDR. A project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for the project was included in the 2006–
2008  regional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  update  for  the  GMS.1 The  ADB  Project 
Preparatory TA Fact-Finding Mission visited the Lao PDR and Thailand from 23 to 31 March 
2006, and reached an understanding with the Government on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing, and terms of reference.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Expansion of high-medium-voltage power transmission lines, and rural electrification are 
crucial for development. Only 47% of households have access to electricity—one of the lowest 
rates in Southeast Asia. The country has no integrated national grid, since the existing high-
voltage transmission lines were developed mainly to enable exporting of electricity from Lao 
PDR hydropower projects and to provide electricity to Vientiane Municipality. Outside the grid, 
rural households and communities have to rely on expensive off-grid power supply, or have no 
electricity. Expensive energy hinders rural development and worsens the rural–urban income 
gap. For sustainable and regionally balanced growth, the Government intends to electrify up to 
90% of total households by 2020 mainly through grid extensions.2  
 
3.    The Government accords top priority to electrification of the northern provinces. Only 
16.1% of households are electrified in Bokeo, Luangnamtha, and Phongsaly provinces—a rate 
much lower than the national average. The northern provinces are among the poorest in the Lao 
PDR, as over 58% of their households are poor, compared with 4.4% in Vientiane Municipality.3 
To eradicate poverty and promote sustainable economic growth, the Government’s priority is to 
provide basic infrastructure, and has called for ADB’s assistance to focus on these provinces.4 
One  priority  measure  to  promote  sustainable  development  is  to  increase  electrification  by 
extending transmission lines.  
 
4.   The Government is keen to support regional cooperation in the power sector. The Lao 
PDR has about 18,000 megawatts (MW) of hydropower potential, of which only 690 MW have 
been harnessed. The Government intends to develop export-oriented power projects to earn

foreign exchange. Despite this hydropower potential, the Lao PDR depends on power from 
neighboring countries. For example, in the border areas, which are isolated from the power grid, 
the Lao PDR imports electricity at medium voltage from neighboring countries. For the northern 
Thai–Lao PDR border areas, the Lao PDR receives limited power through 22-kilovolt (kV) lines 
from the Provincial Electricity Authority of Thailand at Houayxay (Bokeo province) and Kenthao 
(Xayaboury province). The Lao PDR and Thailand have exchanged power for more than 30 
years since the commissioning of the Nam Ngum 1 hydropower project (155 MW) in 1971, and 
have a good long-term relationship. 
 
5.   The state-owned Electricité du Laos (EdL) intends to supply electricity to the northern 
rural areas to achieve the Government’s electrification ratio target. EdL is responsible for power 
generation, transmission, and distribution to meet national demand. EdL’s power facilities cover 
the northern, central 1, central 2, and southern regions, serving about 457,000 customers. For 
the power transmission in central 1, including Vientiane Municipality, ADB has helped EdL 
construct a backbone high-voltage (115 kV) transmission network.5 ADB has helped construct 
115  kV  transmission  lines  from  Vientiane  to  Luangprabang  connecting  to  Nam  Ngum  1 
hydropower and Nam Leuk hydropower (60 MW). ADB’s ongoing project will extend the 115 kV 
power grids from Luangprabang to reach Luangnamtha in the north. 
  
6.  In line with Government policy, the project identifies 115 kV transmission lines extending 
across the northern provinces of Bokeo, Luangnamtha, Phongsaly, Oudomxay, Xayaburi, and 
Vientiane. The project also includes five new substations (115 kV/22 kV), and medium- and low-
voltage  distribution  facilities  for  rural  electrification.  The  project  also  upgrades  the 
interconnection  to  Thailand  from  22  kV  to  115  kV  transmission  lines.  Through  the 
interconnections, the Lao PDR will import power from Thailand to serve the northern region in 
the short term, but the two countries expect to exchange power when the hydropower projects 
by independent power producers are completed. The power trade through interconnections will 
provide  significant  economic  and  environmental  benefits  for  each  country  and  the  entire 
subregion. Such trade will enable countries to (i) reduce national investments in the power 
reserves to meet peak demand, (ii) provide a more reliable supply of electricity in case of power 
failure, (iii) reduce operational costs, (iv) reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other pollutants, 
and (v) increase consumers’ access to the least-cost power supply. The proposed project is an 
integral part of the national power development plan to supply electricity to northern Lao PDR 
and complements the GMS program to promote power trading through interconnection with 
neighboring countries.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The project’s impact is to provide more reliable and environmentally sustainable power 
supply to northern Lao PDR and northeastern Thailand. The TA’s outcome will be a feasibility 
study and project design agreed to by ADB and the Government. The study will set out a project

that  is  economically,  financially,  and  technically  feasible,  and  socially  and  environmentally 
acceptable to (i) extend the transmission and distribution facilities in northern Lao PDR, and (ii) 
strengthen power interconnections with Thailand. An initial poverty and social analysis for the 
project is in Appendix 2.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA activities will identify a project suitable for funding under an ADB loan. The TA 
scope  will  cover  115  kV  transmission  lines  (731  km)  in  northern  Lao  PDR,  comprising 
(i) Houayxay  (Lao  PDR–Thai  border)–Luangnamtha  (146  km),  Namo–Boun  Neua  (96  km); 
(ii) Kenthao (Lao PDR–Thai border)–Paklay–Hongsa (219 km), Nonhai–Paklay (104 km); and 
(iii) Hongsa–Nam Beng–Houayxay (136 km), five substations (Houayxay, Boun Neua, Namo, 
Hongsa, and Paklay), and erection of medium- (22 kV) and low-voltage (400 V) distribution 
facilities. Activities will include (i) reviewing all studies relating to power system development in 
the  Lao  PDR  and  Thailand;  (ii)  assessing  electricity  demand  in  northern  Lao  PDR;  (iii) 
conducting the optimal power system expansion simulation, applying least-cost methods; (iv) 
carrying out engineering line surveys and undertaking load flow studies in the Lao PDR and 
Thailand; (v) preparing preliminary design and technical specifications; (vi) conducting economic 
and financial analyses under ADB policies and guidelines; (vii) reviewing and updating EdL’s 
financial management capacity; and (viii) ensuring safeguard compliance with relevant ADB 
environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples policies and guidelines. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The TA’s total cost is estimated at $950,000 equivalent, comprising $550,000 in foreign 
exchange and $400,000 equivalent in local currency. ADB will finance $800,000 equivalent. The 
TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of 
Japan. The Government of the Lao PDR will finance the remaining $150,000 equivalent of local 
currency costs through in-kind contributions. The contribution will include office accommodation 
and facilities, counterpart staff, data, and other information needed for the TA. Detailed cost 
estimates and a financing plan are in Appendix 3. The Government of the Lao PDR has been 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  EdL  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The  general  manager  of  EdL  will  have  overall 
responsibility for the TA, and will set up a subunit staffed with counterpart personnel for day-to-
day  coordination.  The  team  of  counterpart  personnel  consists  of  power  system  planning 
engineers, transmission and distribution engineers, environment and social management staff 
for the study, accounting staff, staff related to the study, and technical assistants. The personnel 
will  work  with  the  TA  consultant’s  personnel  as  well  as  other  government  agencies, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and other interested parties on environment, indigenous 
peoples, resettlement, and power sector policy issues. 
 
11.  The TA will require about 46 person-months of consulting services, including about 16 
international and about 30 national. The study will be completed in 10 months, from October 
2006 to July 2007. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
12.  The consultant will submit following reports to EdL and ADB: 
(i)  an inception report, within 1 month after services start; 
(ii)  an interim report, at the end of the fourth month of services;

4   
(iii)  a draft final report, a draft resettlement plan, and a draft resettlement framework, 
at the end of the seventh month, presenting all aspects of the study results, 
including surveys, findings, and recommendations; and 
(iv)  a final report, 1 month after receiving comments on the draft final report from EdL 
and ADB. 
 
13.  The consultant will submit brief progress reports to EdL and ADB monthly. Tripartite 
meetings will be held after the submission of the inception, interim, and draft final reports to EdL 
and ADB. A workshop will be held after submission of the draft final report to present the project 
to the Government, NGOs, and other stakeholders.  
 
14.   The  international  consultants  shall  have  expertise  in  power  system  planning, 
transmission,  distribution  lines,  substations,  economic  analysis,  financial  analysis, 
environmental  assessment,  resettlement,  indigenous  peoples  and  ethnic  minorities,  social 
development issues, and institutional development. The national consultants will have expertise 
in  power  system  planning,  transmission,  distribution  lines,  substations,  economic  analysis, 
financial  analysis,  environmental  assessment,  resettlement,  indigenous  peoples  and  ethnic 
minorities, and social development issues. The consultants will be engaged by ADB under its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and its Borrowers. Consultants will be recruited using 
quality- and cost-based selection procedures; simplified technical proposals will be requested. 
TA-financed  equipment  will  be  procured  under  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  Equipment 
purchased under the TA will be handed over to EdL at the end of the services.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for preparing the Greater Mekong 
Subregion Northern Power Transmission Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic: 
Expansion of high-medium-voltage power transmission lines, and rural electrification are crucial for development. Only 
47% of households have access to electricity—one of the lowest rates in Southeast Asia. The country has no 
integrated national grid, since the existing high-voltage transmission lines were developed mainly to enable exporting 
of electricity from Lao PDR hydropower projects and to provide electricity to Vientiane Municipality. Outside the grid, 
rural households and communities have to rely on expensive off-grid power supply, or have no electricity. Expensive 
energy hinders rural development and worsens the rural–urban income gap. For sustainable and regionally balanced 
growth, the Government intends to electrify up to 90% of total households by 2020 mainly through grid extensions.  
 
The Government accords top priority to electrification of the northern provinces. Only 16.1% of households are 
electrified in Bokeo, Luangnamtha, and Phongsaly provinces—a rate much lower than the national average. The 
northern provinces are among the poorest in the Lao PDR, as over 58% of their households are poor, compared with 
4.4% in Vientiane Municipality. To eradicate poverty and promote sustainable economic growth, the Government’s 
priority is to provide basic infrastructure, and has called for ADB’s assistance to focus on these provinces. One priority 
measure to promote sustainable development is to increase electrification by extending transmission lines. 
 
Access to modern sources of energy and subsidized energy (grid) in particular, is an equity issue. Most of the rural 
households and poor do not have access to grid, and pay indirectly for subsidies that do not benefit them. Under the 
proposed project, grid expansion and distribution lines would provide opportunities for rural electrification and 
industrialization in the project areas. Improved electric supply will lift a significant constraint on economic growth. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Following ADB’s Enhanced Poverty Reduction Strategy (2004), projects classified as general intervention no longer 
require project poverty assessment. However, a social assessment will be conducted to prepare a resettlement plan 
and ethnic minority group-related activities, as well as for an HIV/AIDS and STD awareness program.  
 
The core analysis will be prepared from primary and secondary data. Primary data will be collected from sample 
survey and focus group discussion and/or participatory appraisal.   
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Previous ADB technical assistance (TA) projects such as TA 3087-LAO: Northern Area Rural Power Distribution, TA 
3756-LAO: Roads for Rural Development Project, and TA 3817-LAO: Northern Economic Corridor Project a cover the 
same project included in the proposed TA. During the preparation of these TAs, consultations and meetings were held 
with affected households, relevant stakeholders, and Electricité du Laos.

A participatory stakeholder workshop will be an integral part of social analysis for resettlement, an ethnic minority plan, 
or ethnic minority groups' specific action and gender strategy. Ethnic minority groups will be consulted separately on 
their specific issues. 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The socioeconomic data will be disaggregated by gender and ethnic group. A project-specific gender strategy with 
budget will be prepared and a gender-related strategy incorporated into the resettlement plan and ethnic minority 
groups’ related plan and activities.  Gender-disaggregated monitoring indicators by ethnic group will be developed to 
assess the impact of resettlement. Monitoring indicators will include monitoring HIV/AIDS in the project area.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The consultants will ensure that all works and outputs under the technical assistance 
(TA) fully comply with all relevant Asian Development Bank (ADB) policies and guidelines. The 
international consultant will select national consultants as associates to (i) assist international 
consultants; (ii) collect information; (iii) carry out engineering, social, and environment surveys; 
and (iv) organize and prepare public consultations.    
A.   Scope of Work 
1.  Team  Leader  and  Power  System,  Transmission,  Distribution  Line  and 
Substation  Engineers  (3.5  person-months,  team  leader,  international;  3.0 
person-months,  transmission,  substation,  distribution,  and  power  system 
engineer,  international;  2.0  person-months,  power  system  engineer,  national; 
total  6.0  person-months,  two  transmission  line  and  substation  engineers, 
national; total 6.0 person-months, two distribution line engineers, national)  
2.  The team leader will ensure the consistency and quality of the various aspects of the 
study. The team leader will be one of the consultants in the power system, transmission, and 
substation, and is not a separate position. 
3.  The  power  system,  transmission,  distribution  line,  and  substation  engineers  will 
undertake, but will not be limited to, the following tasks: (i) Review relevant studies relating to 
the  power  system  development  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  and 
Thailand.  (ii)  In  collaboration  with  the  project  economist,  review  relevant  data  and  reports 
relating to power demand forecast in the Lao PDR. Conduct a 30-year load demand forecast for 
the proposed project in the Lao PDR in terms of residential, commercial, industrial, agriculture, 
public services, and other sectors, using econometric or other techniques that incorporate the 
price of electricity. (iii) Conduct desk and field investigations to firm up and update information 
relating  to  power  system  expansion  plans  in  northern  Lao  PDR  and  Thailand.  (iv) In 
collaboration  with  the  project  economist,  conduct  the  optimal  power  system  expansion 
simulation,  applying  least-cost  methods  and  appropriate  technology.  Determine  the  cross-
border transmission and distribution options best suited to meet the estimated demand in the 
project area. (v) Carry out engineering surveys of 115 kV transmission lines, refine the project 
layout, and undertake the power flow studies (power flow analysis, fault current analysis, and 
stability analysis) to determine the conductor sizes, tower configurations, major river crossings, 
substation dimensions, and equipment. (vi) Prepare preliminary design of facility and equipment, 
and technical specifications, taking into account the appropriate power system planning criteria, 
technical  standards,  standard  specification  equipment,  and  the  engineering  practice  of 
Electricité  du  Laos  (EdL)  in  accordance  with  the  approved  Lao  Electric  Power  Technical 
Standards. (vii)  Prepare initial layouts of the subprojects (distribution lines) for providing a 
22 kV bulk power supply to villages. Before preparing the layouts, consult the Government, ADB, 
and  other  donors  to  ensure  coordination  with  any  ongoing  or  proposed  poverty  reduction 
activities  in  the  project  area.  (viii)  Prepare  conceptual  designs  for  new  five  115/22  kV 
substations at Boun Neua, Houayxay, Hongsa, Namo, and Paklay (but not limited to these five); 
and additional bays at existing substations to provide for the new transmission interconnector. 
(ix) Prepare a detailed list of equipment and construction works, and unexplored ordnance 
clearance. Estimate their foreign and local cost components. (x) Determine investment costs for 
consumer  connections  and  costs  to  be  borne  by  the  consumers.  (xi)  Outline  project 
implementation arrangements. Prepare a project implementation schedule taking into account

Appendix 4  11
 
the experience from EdL’s ongoing power distribution projects. Conduct EdL’s procurement 
capacity assessment in accordance with ADB’s project administration instruction 3.01. Prepare 
detailed procurement packages in line with the ADB's Procurement Guidelines. Help draft a 
procurement  plan  for  the  subsequent  loan  project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Project 
Administration Instruction no. 3.01 and ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. (xii) Assist ADB and 
EdL in drafting the project administration memorandum. (xiii) Prepare, coordinate, and conduct 
one workshop each for inception, interim, and final tripartite meetings, and other workshops to 
be  implemented  if  necessary.  (xiv)  Propose  specific  policy  recommendations  and 
implementation measures on institutional improvements and capacity building for power sector 
operational  efficiency,  development  of  renewable  energy,  and  promotion  of  private  sector 
participation.  
2.  Project  Economists  (2.5  person-months,  international;  2.0  person-months, 
national) 
4.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, Handbook 
for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of Projects, Handbook for Integrating 
Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects, and Operations Manual-G1 
on Economic Analysis of Projects (2003), the consultant will undertake, but will not be limited to, 
the following tasks: (i) In collaboration with the power system engineers, review all relevant data 
and reports relating to power demand forecast in the Lao PDR. Conduct a 30-year load demand 
forecast relevant to the proposed project in the Lao PDR in terms of residential, commercial, 
industrial, agriculture, public services, and other sectors using econometric or other techniques 
that incorporate the price of electricity. (ii) In collaboration with the engineers, review the latest 
generation  and  long-term  transmission  expansion  plans  in  the  Lao  PDR.  Determine  likely 
hydropower and thermal power plants development scenarios in the Lao PDR with Ministry of 
Industry  and  Handicrafts,  and  EdL.  (iii) In  collaboration  with  the  power  system  engineers, 
undertake  a  least-cost  analysis  to  determine  the  best  alternative  based  on  different  load 
forecasts,  one  of  which  is  based  on  socially  efficient  electricity  prices.  (iv)  Calculate  the 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for each project section, and the project as a whole. 
Undertake sensitivity analysis by identifying the most critical factors and determine the impact of 
such factors on the EIRR, including varying project cost and benefits, implementation period, 
power demand, and combinations of these factors. Calculate switching values. (v) Conduct a 
risk  analysis  (using  the  Monte  Carlo  method)  by  considering  the  possible  values  for  key 
variables based on past records, and their occurrence probability, in accordance with ADB’s 
Handbook  for  Integrating  Risk  Analysis  in  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.  (vi)  In 
collaboration with relevant specialists, prepare a project framework in the ADB format, including 
monitoring indicators, that will be used to assess project performance, and baseline and target 
values for the selected indicators. 
3.  Financial Analyst (2.5 person-months, international; 2.0 person-months, national) 
5.   In accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005) and 
ADB’s  Operations  Manual-G2  on  Financial  Management  System,  Financial  Analysis,  and 
Financial Performance Indicators (2003), the consultant will undertake the detailed financial 
analysis of the ensuing project and EdL. The consultant will undertake, but will not be limited to, 
the following tasks: (i) Carry out in-depth financial analysis of the proposed investment (and any 
defined subprojects), including calculation of the financial internal rate of return and weighted 
average cost of capital, taking into account all the financial costs and revenues that can be 
attributable to the proposed project. The consultant is expected to determine the transfer pricing 
at the terminal points of the transmission lines to be financed under the project. Conduct 
separate financial analysis for a sample of rural electrification and/or distribution expansion

1  2          Appendix 4 
 
 
projects included in the project.  (ii) Identify all risks to project revenue and costs and conduct 
relevant sensitivity analyses on the financial rate of return of the project. (iii) Prepare a financing 
plan  for  the  project  that  includes  proposed  ADB  lending,  prospective  cofinancing,  and 
appropriate  counterpart  funds  for  local  currency  expenditures,  with  price  and  physical 
contingencies. (iv) Review the historical financial performance of EdL during 1999–2005 and 
comments on EdL’s compliance with financial covenants set by international financing institutes. 
Comment on the adequacy of present tariff levels to ensure the financial viability of EdL. (v) 
Prepare  financial  projections  for  EdL  for  2006–2016,  taking  into  account  the  proposed 
investment program, borrowings, and forecasted demand growth. Propose prudent financial 
covenants to ensure that EdL generate adequate cash flows to finance new investments and to 
repay its loans (self-financing ratio and debt–equity ratio). (vi) Prepare an appendix to the report 
and recommendation of the President, briefly summarizing past historical and projected financial 
performance that includes a 10-year pro forma financial statements (balance sheet, income 
statement, and statement of cash flows) for EdL. (vii) Assess EdL’s financial management 
capabilities that includes a review of earlier ADB and other lender studies of EdL, and make any 
recommendations for institutional strengthening of financial management, with a time-bound 
implementation plan. Prepare an assessment of the financial management and/or fiduciary 
arrangements of the project management unit for the proposed project.   
4.  Environmental Assessment Specialist (2.0 person-months, international; total 
6.0 person-months, two environmental assessment specialist, national) 
6.  In  accordance  with  ADB  policies  and  guidelines  on  environment  assessment,  in 
particular  Environment  Policy  (2003),  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines  (2003),  ADB’s 
Operations  Manual-F1  on  Environment  Considerations  (2003),  and  the  Government’s 
environmental safeguard requirements, the consultant will undertake, but will not be limited to, 
the following tasks: (i) Conduct an initial environmental examination (IEE) and summary IEE 
(SIEE) for the project and determine the need for an environmental impact assessment.  The 
study shall cover various project components such as transmission lines, substations, and 
distribution lines, taking into account the likely impacts associated with their locations, designs, 
and construction activities. The IEE should also include the long-term and cumulative impacts 
during operation and identify environmental issues from activities directly induced by the project 
such as access roads. Pay special attention to the project’s proximity and anticipated impacts to 
culturally and ecologically protected areas such as the national biodiversity conservation areas. 
(ii) Prepare a specific environmental management plan (EMP) for the project which includes 
monitoring program (monitoring indicator, frequency, and reporting requirements), recommend 
mitigating measures, specific budget, and institutional arrangements to implement the mitigation 
measures and monitoring plan. Identify and prepare capacity-building programs needed to 
implement the EMP.  Assess the environmental benefits of the proposed EMP activities, and 
propose follow-up mechanisms to ensure their effectiveness. (iii) Organize and document public 
consultations  at  least  once  in  every  province  with  sites  of  major  project  components,  in 
accordance with ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005).  Local stakeholders should be 
invited to the public consultations as much as possible. (iv) Conduct, as relevant, environmental 
due  diligence  on  the  safeguard  requirements  and  performance  of  any  major  “associated 
facilities” to the proposed project, identify the gaps as compared with the national and ADB 
environmental safeguard requirements, recommend solutions or action plans to address the 
gaps, and summarize the results into the IEE/SIEE. (v) Work closely with Science Technology 
and Environment Agency, Science Technology and Environment Office (provincial), and EdL to 
confirm that the environmental management plan is practical and meaningful.

Appendix 4  13
 
5.  Resettlement  and  Ethnic  Minority  Specialists  (2.5  person-months, 
international;  total  6.0  person-months,  two  resettlement  and  ethnic  minority 
specialist, national) 
7.  In accordance with, and relevant policies and guidelines of ADB, in particular Policy on 
Involuntary Resettlement (1995), Handbook on Resettlement (1998), Operations Mannual-F2 on 
Involuntary  Resettlement  (2003),  Operations  Manual-F3  on  Indigenous  People  (2004), 
Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis (2001), and Handbook for Incorporation of Social 
Dimensions in Projects (1994), the consultant will undertake, but will not be limited to, the 
following  tasks:  (i)  Prepare  sample-based  socioeconomic  profiles  of  the  affected  people 
identified  in  the  inventory  of  affected  people,  highlighting  ethnic  minority-  and  gender-
disaggregated data and impacts. (ii) Prepare a resettlement framework for the distribution lines 
and a resettlement plan for the transmission lines and substations, in close consultation with 
and  full  participation  of  stakeholders,  including  EdL;  based  on  preliminary  engineering 
alignment; and a full census and inventory of lost assets of affected people inclusive of the non-
titled. For the section Houayxay–Luangnamtha along with ADB’s Route 3 project, conduct and 
prepare a due diligence report which provides a status update on resettlement activities and any 
outstanding issues, including the need if any to prepare a retrofitted resettlement plan for the 
right of way along the road. (iii) Identify the communes and/or villages and number of ethnic 
minority households which will be affected by the project. Conduct participatory appraisal with 
the  various  stakeholders  (men,  women,  youth,  village  leaders,  and  leaders  of  the  mass 
organizations) from the affected villages and collect information for socioeconomic profile of the 
ethnic minority groups. In addition to primary data, collect secondary data from the social 
analysis reports of TA 3087-LAO, TA 3756-LAO, and TA 3817-LAO1. Based on the primary and 
secondary data, prepare socioeconomic profiles (by gender and ethnic minority groups) of the 
project-affected area. (iv) Review and assess the potential scope and impacts of the project on 
ethnic minorities. If ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) will be triggered by the project, 
prepare an ethnic minorities development plan in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous 
Peoples (1998) and Operations Manual, Section F3. If a stand-alone EMDP is not necessary, 
prepare  specific  provisions  in  the  resettlement  plan  to  address  the  needs  of  such  ethnic 
minorities and are consistent with ADB’s policies and procedures on indigenous peoples and/or 
ethnic minorities. (v) Collect data on the socioeconomic condition of women in the project area 
including land titling for women. Assess the extent to which women’s work in agriculture and 
forest and livelihood of households headed by poor women will be affected by resettlement 
and/or land acquisition in the project area. Prepare a gender strategy that includes capacity 
building training of resettlement committee members, women’s union, EdL for planning and 
implementation  of  a  gender-sensitive  resettlement  plan.  Incorporate  gender  strategy  and 
capacity  building  training  program  in  the  resettlement  plan  and  in  the  relevant  project 
components.  Incorporate  in  the  resettlement  plan,  a  budget  for  gender  strategy,  including 
capacity building training. (vi) Prepare a public consultation and disclosure plan to ensure that 
EdL has consulted all affected people and obtain their views about the project and resettlement 
effects, resettlement entitlements, and options on compensation and assistance. (vii) Assist EdL 
in the timely disclosure of the resettlement framework and resettlement plan. (viii) Assist EdL in 
the timely disclosure of ethnic minority development plan (as relevant). (ix) Assess the capacity 
of the responsible central and provincial institutions to plan, manage, implement, finance, and 
monitor the resettlement plan- and ethnic minority-related issues and identify any capacity-
                                                 
1   ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Preparing the Northern Area Rural 
Power  Distribution  Project.  Manila  (TA  3087-LAO);  ADB.  2001.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic for Preparing the Road for Rural Development Project. Manila (TA 3756-LAO); and ADB. 
2002. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Preparing the Northern Economic 
Corridor Project. Manila (TA 3817-LAO).

1  4          Appendix 4 
 
 
building measures that need to be included in the project. (x) Prepare terms of reference for an 
external monitor to monitor and evaluate resettlement implementation and independently report 
to ADB on resettlement issues. (xi) Carry out resettlement training workshops for the affected 
people and other stakeholders in the project-affected area. (xii) Review and assess the risk of 
spreading HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) during the construction 
phase.  Review  the  HIV/AIDS  awareness  program  under  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
Northern Economic Corridor Project2 and identify lessons in designing HIV/AIDS and STD 
awareness program. Prepare the budget for HIV/AIDS and STDs awareness program and 
conditions in the contractors’ contracts. (xiii) Develop disaggregated monitoring indicators by 
ethnic  groups  and  gender  for  resettlement  and  ethnic  minority-related  activities  and  for 
HIV/AIDS and STD awareness program.   
B.  Reporting and Workshop Requirements 
 
8.  The consultants will prepare the following reports for EdL and ADB: (i) inception report, 
within 1 month after services start; (ii) an interim report, within 4 months of start of services; (iii) 
a draft final report, a draft resettlement plan, and a draft resettlement framework, within 7 
months,  presenting  all  aspects  of  the  study  results,  including  surveys,  findings, 
recommendations, suggested approaches to implementation, and all other matters leading to a 
recommended project for possible ADB financing; and (iv) a final report 1 month after comments 
on the draft final report are received from EdL and ADB. The consultants will also prepare 
monthly status reports based on the implementation and staffing schedules in the inception 
report, highlighting any issues that could become critical for the timely completion of the TA and 
that require attention from EdL and ADB. 
9.  Tripartite meetings will be held in Vientiane after submission of the inception, interim, 
and draft final reports. A workshop will be held in Vientiane after submission of the draft final 
report to present the project to the governments, nongovernment organizations, and other 
stakeholders. 
 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2002. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic for the Greater Mekong Subregion: Northern Economic Corridor Project. Manila 
(Loan 1989-LAO).
